metadata.case_name: State of Bihar v. Bata Shoe Co. Ltd. and Workmen

facts.text: Workmen of Bata Shoe Co. Ltd. factory at Digha formed a union at the close of the last World War, with president Mr. John and general secretary Mr. Fateh Narain Singh.

On June 22, 1947, the company entered into a collective agreement with the union, settling Standing Orders and Rules certified under the Industrial Employment Standing Orders Act of 1946; union recognised as sole collective bargaining agency.
Towards end of 1954, two groups formed in union: one led by Mr. Fateh Narain Singh, other by Mr. Bari; rivalry grew.
On January 22, 1954, union through Mr. Fateh Narain Singh served slowdown notice effective February 24, 1954.
On February 6, 1954, Mr. Bari, purporting as president, asked followers to strike from February 23, 1954.
Demands by Mr. Fateh Narain Singh led to conciliation, settled on February 8, 1954.
Despite settlement, some workmen including 60 in question (supporting Mr. Bari) went on illegal strike on February 23, 1954; bound by settlement as union members.
Majority opposed strike; letter signed by 500 workmen on February 16, 1954, disassociating from strike.
Strike partial: out of 854 workmen, nearly 500 attended despite threats.
Strike declared illegal by government under s.23(c) of the Act.
Company served charge-sheets; dismissed 274 workmen including 60 in question.
Union negotiated with company: agreed 110 strikers employed (76 already employed); 30 remain dismissed; 30 cases for later reemployment.
60 workmen did not demand reinstatement individually or collectively; no other organisation raised their case.
Agreement ended dispute regarding dismissed strikers as far as union concerned.
Conciliation officer Mr. Sinha wrote on September 3, 1954, desiring conciliation for some dismissed workmen; dispute not sponsored by any organisation.
Union secretary wrote to Commissioner of Labour on September 22, 1954, objecting to reference of 60 workmen's dispute.
Government of Bihar referred dispute on October 8, 1954 (Notification No. III DI-1602/54-L-15225) re 31 workmen (Ref. No. 10 of 1954) to tribunal with Mr. Ali Hassan.
On January 15, 1955 (Notification No. III DI-1601/55 L. 696), similar reference for 29 other workmen (Ref. No. 1 of 1955) to same tribunal.
Proceedings consolidated, pending and progressed.

On September 17, 1955 (Notification No. III DI-1601/55-L-13028), government purported to supersede earlier notifications, combine disputes, implead 60 workmen, add Bata Mazdoor Union, refer to same tribunal.
Tribunal on September 19, 1955, cancelled hearing of prior references fixed for October 3, 1955, closed files.
Bata Company and workmen filed M.J.C. Nos. 546 and 590 of 1955 in Patna High Court under Arts. 226/227 praying to quash third notification.

Patna High Court on April 4, 1956, held government had no power to supersede, allowed applications, issued certiorari quashing Sept 17 notification, mandamus to tribunal to proceed with Refs 10/1954 and 1/1955 expeditiously.
State of Bihar obtained leave from Supreme Court on June 26, 1956; appeals by special leave.
On May 30, 1955, union applied to tribunal alleging majority opposed reinstatement of 60 workmen, no interest; other applications by workmen to join as opposed rejected.
Mr. Fateh Narain Singh moved Dept of Labour, Bihar; third notification issued pursuant thereto, adding his union.

legal_issues.text: Where an industrial dispute has been referred to a tribunal for adjudication by the appropriate government under s. 10(1)(d) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, can the said government supersede the said reference pending adjudication before the tribunal constituted for that purpose?

petitioner_arguments.text: Government acted bona fide in interests of fair-play, justice, convenience, industrial peace; necessary to hear union, refer comprehensively with all parties.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Implied power under s.10(1) ID Act; s.21 General Clauses Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Power to cancel/supersede implied as per s.21 General Clauses Act, which includes power to rescind notifications.
If dispute settled pending reference, need to cancel to give effect.
Reliance on Minerva Mills: government can withdraw reference to one tribunal and refer to another.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Minerva Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen (1954 SCR 465)

respondent_arguments.text: Third notification illegal and ultra vires; government has no power/authority to supersede earlier notifications.

court_reasoning.text: Bona fides irrelevant; if no authority to cancel, bona fides cannot validate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act does not expressly confer power to cancel/supersede reference under s.10(1); must examine if implied.

court_reasoning.text: s.21 General Clauses Act is rule of construction; depends on scheme, context, effect of ID Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of ID Act inconsistent with power to cancel.

court_reasoning.text: Policy of Act: secure industrial peace via conciliation first, adjudication last; once referred under s.10(1), proceedings commence (s.20(3)), tribunal seized; government outside except s.10(5).
Inconsistent with proviso s.10 (public utility must refer), s.10(2) (mandatory if majority), s.12(5) (reasons if no reference).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reasons needed for cancel, unlike no-reference.

court_reasoning.text: If settled pending, tribunal can award in terms of settlement; no need to cancel.
s.10(3), s.33 impose status quo during pendency; cancel would affect obligations.
No principle supports absolute implied power to cancel without conditions.
Distinguished Minerva Mills (no cancel, new tribunal after old ceased); Strawboard (obiter/argument); others erroneous.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.21 not applicable to s.10(1) ID Act.

holdings.text: Appropriate government has no power to cancel or supersede a reference made under s.10(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

precedents_cited.case_name: Minerva Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: No question of cancelling s.10(1) order; new tribunal after old ceased.

precedents_cited.case_name: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Passage cited was argument of counsel, not court's view; no decision on cancel power.

precedents_cited.case_name: Textile Workers Union, Amritsar v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Held power implied via s.21 Gen Clauses; erroneous.

precedents_cited.case_name: Iyyappen Mills Private Ltd., Trichur v. State of Travancore-Cochin
precedents_cited.relevance: First tribunal ceased; supported by Minerva.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harendranath Bose v. Second Industrial Tribunal
South India Estate Labour Relations Organisation v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Amendment of reference for new matters ok as independent reference.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Scheme precludes power to cancel reference under s.10(1); once referred, tribunal seized; status quo, finality of awards.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Rule of construction for power to rescind notifications; not applicable to s.10(1) ID Act due to repugnancy.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Certified standing orders settled by agreement.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes (Appellate Tribunal) Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Recognised awards with consent of parties.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court confirms Patna High Court order: notification of September 17, 1955, cancelling earlier references invalid and ultra vires; directs final order accordingly.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of certiorari quashing impugned notification upheld; mandamus to tribunal to proceed with original references upheld.

key_quotes.text: If the appellant has no authority to cancel or revoke a notification issued under s.10(1), the bona fides of the appellant can hardly validate the impugned cancellation.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bona fides irrelevant without statutory power.

key_quotes.text: We have no hesitation in holding that the rule of construction enunciated by s.21 of the General Clauses Act in so far as it refers to the power of rescinding or cancelling the original order cannot be invoked in respect of the provisions of s.10(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The scheme of the provisions in Chapters III and IV of the Act would thus appear to be to leave the reference proceedings exclusively within the jurisdiction of the tribunals constituted under the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
